title.narrative: Working with Men to Increase Security and Stabilization in North Kivu, South Kivu and Ituri provinces

description.narrative: 1. Husband’s women survivors SGBV in Community; 2. Military Men; 3. PoliceMen (PNC); 4. Men living in Community in high risk zones; 5. Ex-combatant and ex child soldiers living in Community in high risk zones; 6. Spouses of military men and policemen participating into the LP program

The Living Peace project seeks to achieve its goal by pursuing following objectives at five different levels: 1. Individuel Level: Men and women (spouses), healed of severe mental health and psychosocial problems, adopted positive non-violent coping strategies and experience greater personal efficacy to build meaningful relations with self and others. 2. Family Level: Reduced violence at home and restored peaceful partner relations create a safe and healthy environment for women, men and children. Reduction of violence use by men against their partners and children and increase gender equitable behaviours in the household create a safer environment for all members of the family. 3. Community Level: Restored community-based social support systems increase social cohesion between families, individuals and community structures resulting in higher levels of inclusion, and solidarity between community members. 4. Society Level: Congolese civil society organizations and public institutions of Police, Army and Health Care and religious leaders institutionalized the Living Peace approach in their services to adequately address the consequences of SGBV, promote positive masculinity and prevent (mainly) men getting involved in conflicts and/or (re)join armed groups. 5. Women Social and Economic Empowerment: Women, partners of male participants in Living Peace groups, enjoy greater social and economic autonomy with positive support of husbands that participated in Living Peace groups.

The goal of the proposed intervention is to achieve sustainable, gender-equitable peace at all levels of society in provinces of South Kivu, North Kivu and Ituri in eastern DRC by: 1. The overall goal of LPI is to reduce level of violence and build trust in the community by working with men through psychosocial support programs that will help them to end violence and adopt norms and values that support gender equality at all levels; 2. Promoting women socio-economic empowerment with positive support of husbands through an adaptation of the Living Peace methodology, (Journeys of Transformation). LPI will partner with a local organization that is implementing VSLA groups and/or women involved in other economic empowerment activities. LPI will train the local partner in the application of Journeys of Transformation module to engage men as allies of women in economic empowerment.

title.narrative: Output 4.1: Congolese government and civil society organizations (CSOs) trained to engage men in ending SGBV

description.narrative: At society level LP have the objective of involving Congolese civil society and public institutions in order to institutionalize the Living Peace approach and influence policy. Living Peace Institute transfers the message of peace to local CSOs and Congolese government institutions to persuade them to take responsibility and action against SGBV, starting with SGBV between uniformed men and civilians. Living Peace builds the capacity of state actors and CSOs, by engaging them in activities and debates, and by actively participating in all technical working groups and platforms that seek to end SGBV

title.narrative: Mentorship and clinical supervisions

description.narrative: LPI continues strengthening the quality of the intervention through mentorship and clinical supervision that involves LP facilitators, technical supervisors, project coordinators (or assistant coordinators). The purpose of clinical supervision is to provide a safe and confident environment for project staff to reflect on and discuss their work and their personal and professional response to their work. The focus is on supporting staff personal and professional development and reflection on their practice, critical analysis of LP group evolution to ensure quality service for participants and the psychosocial well being of the facilitators by helping them to learn to cope positively with distress which should resulting from both working environment and personal life experiences.

title.narrative: Number of facilitators who benefited from clinical supervision

description.narrative: 222 facilitators among them 172 men and 50 women participated in the first clinical supervision. Individual and group supervision are designed to help LP group facilitators to effectively deal with the double burden resulting in the their daily exposure to stressful and distressing situations in their community and their first role as helpers in listen LP group participants painful experience.

title.narrative: Output 3.3: Ex-combatants and ex-child soldiers specifically targeted and actively engaged in LP Program psychosocial support groups

description.narrative: LPI is working with ex-combatants and ex-child soldiers in Kirotche and Mweso health zones to help them to address a range of psychosocial challenges during their transition to civilian life in order to increase their prospects for successful reintegration. This includes the healing of individual and social trauma; reduce the effects of stigma and exclusion in order to create a space that facilitates the process of reconciliation between ex-combatants, their families and communities. In the context of the on-going conflict in eastern DRC, it seems that the social fabric is extremely weak. The fragmented nature of society is a serious obstacle to the reintegration process of ex-combatants. The building of social capital through the expansion of social networks, and then the more general establishment of social cohesion in the community, should be at the heart of the processes of social reintegration.

title.narrative: Collaboration and synergy

description.narrative: Living Peace Institute continues to carry out its collaboration and synergies with other local and international NGO as well as UN agencies and government institutional in order to increase security and stability in North Kivu, South Kivu and Ituri province. The aims of this collaboration and synergy are to share knowledge and experiences on GBV prevention approaches through meetings, workshops and different working groups clusters in DRC.

title.narrative: Meetings and conferences

description.narrative:
During the first semester (October 2020-March 2021), LPI actively participated in different national, regional and international platforms to reach more men, women and decision makers and focusing on positive masculinity and message related to gender-equitable peace. -On 21 st January, LPI through its provincial coordination in ituri attended the meeting during which the annual plan of the GBV sub-cluster was presented. The actors have shown that they are many cases of SGBV in BOGA health zone, but there is no actor working there. -Monthly Sub Cluster meeting on GBV chaired by UNFPA, this meeting aims to strengthen the provincial coordination to combat gender-based violence in humanitarian situation in South Kivu. In South Kivu, LPI attended two meetings on January 28th and March 25th 2021. This was an opportunity to all partners to update the mapping of its intervention areas in order to respond rationally to the GBV gaps and to show the progress of their activities.
-On January 20th and March 03rd 2021, LPI South Kivu Office participated to the Technical Working Group on accountability and Protection Against Sexual and Exploitation Abuse cluster chaired by UNFPA. The meeting is organized on monthly basis with the aim to have regular alerts on protection of the population in the context of humanitarian settings. -On 04th March 2021 LPI through its south kivu coordination participated in Gender Technical Working Group chaired by the Provincial Minister of Gender, Health, Social and Humanitarian affairs to update gender sector interventions with partners at province level. On January 27th and 03rd March 2021 LPI participated on Sexual Reproductive Health led by the South Kivu Health Division to discuss on the VBG data in the different health zones. -On 21 st January, LPI through its provincial coordination in ituri attended the meeting during which the annual plan of the GBV sub-cluster was presented. The actors have shown that they are many cases of SGBV in BOGA health zone, but there is no actor working there. -On March 18, LPI ituri attended the GBV sub-cluster. The meeting focused on mapping post-rape kits and the referral circuit in the event of GBV. Alert phone numbers have been given. -Through GBV sub-cluster LPI is already linked with the child protection-working group whose lead is held by UNICEF and participated in the training organised by UNICEF with the objective of capacity building on different tools in child protection.
-On March 31 st 2021, LPI-Sud Kivu provincial coordination collaborated with the section of Gender affair at MONUSCO to organise a round table in order to reflect on positive masculinity and non violent behaviours to promote positive and gender equitable relations. 45 Military and Police officers attended the event. -On 16 April 2021, OSESG and ICGLR Gender Advisors facilitated a briefing session for Civil Society Organisations (CSOs) in which Living Peace Institute participate to appraise them on the recent engagements of the Special Envoy with UN Security Council, with a focus on the regional strategy and the related Plan of Action. C SOs were informed that they will be invited to contribute in the development of the Plan of Action. Participants were also briefed on the ongoing efforts relating to the security cooperation process and the planned workshop in Goma (DRC) for the launch of the Contact and Coordination Group (CCG), scheduled to take place in late April. In attendance where representatives of the Executive Secretariat of the ICGLR, the Chief of Staff of the DRC National Oversight Mechanism (NOM), ICGLR Fora and regional CSOs, in addition to ICGLR and O/SESG substantive staff members. The meeting discussed the importance of the non-military approach to security and the need to have a comprehensive involvement of CSOs, including women and youth. It was proposed that the areas of focus should include messaging addressed to armed groups, engaging their leadership, promoting DDR and creating job opportunities to contribute to stability. Participants recommended that the CCG also takes into account the important role played by communities that receive the disengaged members of the armed groups.

title.narrative: Output 3. Military men and police specifically targeted and actively engaged in LP Program psychosocial support groups

description.narrative: Living Peace groups with police and military men as participants aim to influence both the private and professional behavior of the participants. By learning positive and non-violent coping strategies, including management of power relations in the household and in the workplace, the role of the male participants as protectors of the community will improve. In turn, better relationships with community members will result in more adequate responses to SGBV and its prevention.

title.narrative: Output 5.1: Target women actively participate in VSLAs meeting in selected communities.

description.narrative: Spouses of military men and policemen participating into the LP program are organized into Village Savings and Loan Associations (VSLAs). The husbands of those women participated in LP groups and adopted non-violent and positive attitudes in partner relations due to the therapeutic groups.

title.narrative: Output indicators 5.1.1.Number of field officers trained in the VSLA approach to support existing and to create new VSLAs in target communities

description.narrative: 2 field officers and 4 field agents were trained on VSLA implementation and supervision. The trainings focused on how to undertake effective community mobilizations towards the formation of a VSLA, to ensure that community leaders understand the intervention and its contribution to their respective communities, to secure the commitment of the VSLA members in the communities to form and run VSLA, equip VSLA members with knowledge and skills to effectively manage and benefit from a VSLA, to inculcate the savings culture among VSLA members, inculcate a culture of planning and savings for emergencies, to ensure effective functionality and operations of VSLA

title.narrative: Output indicators 5.1.2.Number of VSLAs groups of women organized and fully functioning in selected communities.

description.narrative: Prior to the formation of VSLA groups, centre Rafiki, in collaboration with LPI and ISL a two week sensitization campaigns on behalf of the women and their husbands to raise their awareness on the services offered by the VSLA, and detailed description of how a VSLA works and its link with the LP psychosocial targeting men; what people have to do to participate and the role of the implementing organization.After sensitisation, spouses of military men and policemen who manifested the willingness to participate in VSLA were gathered in 30 VSLA groups. Note that a VSLA group is composed of 25 members. 15 VSLA group are located in Katindo Military camp, 9 VSLA groups are located in Munzenze Police camp , 6 groups are located at Mugunga police Academy.

title.narrative: Output indicator 5.1.3. Number of women actively attended VSLAs shared sessions

description.narrative: VSLAs are implemented in tree main phases. The Preparatory phase, which consists of providing general information to local leaders and prospective VSLA members covered the 3 first weeks of February 2021. The Intensive phase that lasts approxmativery 14 weeks started on the 22 nd of February with consecutive training meetings aiming at helping the association elects its leaders, establishes its constitution and sets out the rules and procedures that govern financial activities. It then continues to meetings, in which the Association learns to manage social fund, share-purchase/savings and loan transactions. For the reporting period (January to 31 march, 2021), 5 sessions were covered and no shared session has been implemented yet. Note that shared sessions are 7th, 10th, 14th, 24th, 29th, 33rd and 36th. statistics show that the average rate of participation in VSLA sessions is 97.3%. This means that 24 women per group participate regularly in VSLA sessions

title.narrative: Output 3.4: Religious and community leaders trained in gender transformative approaches to restoring social cohesion

description.narrative: Training religious leaders in the Living Peace methodology will help them reach out to members of their religious communities while applying a methodology that combines promotion of gender equality, mental health care prevention and psychosocial support. Also, community leaders will be included and trained as facilitators. Inclusion of religious leaders and community leaders encourages community members to join efforts of Living Peace Institute to end SGBV in communities, prevent violence and respond more adequately to cases of violence in the community. As leaders they are important role models for the community by adhering to gender equality and promoting nonviolent masculinity.

description.narrative: During the first term of the VSLA implementation, LPI trained 60 women from 30 VSLA groups on cross cutting issues including: gender stereotypes and norms, Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) and Sexual and Gender-Based Violence (VSBG), power relations and decision-making in the home, joint management of economic affairs and many others.
